The course seems to lack direction.  We learned about topics in a piece-meal sort of way that made an overarching theme difficult to parse.  The problem sets were consistently confusing (What does it mean for a population density to be measured in one dimension? That doesn't make any sense whatsoever.  Are 286 humans standing in one single-file line? Even if it's 286 humans in the circle with a one-mile radius, what, is it another 286 in the next circle with a 2-mile radius?  Is it a series of concentric circles each with the same number but a proportionately decreasing density of humans?  What kind of world is this?  We can calculate the area of a circle in square miles, which is the standard unit for population density in the US, and then multiply that number of square miles by the average population density per square mile to get the estimated population for that given region.  When I asked about this, I was told that it was designed to make the concept "simpler" to us but it is in fact more confusing.). Also, more diversity in variables is important.  For example, "D" is meant to be "demand" "density" "damage" and other d-words, and things start to get a little unclear.  Apart from the disjointed nature of the course, it's all very interesting.  Furthermore, students seemed to be getting different educations one discussion section to the next.

I went to office hours several times, did the pset with the TF who was grading that week, and still didn't do well. Also, there's huge variance in grading - the same answers on psets were graded differently. The midterm was a mess, with questions that didn't actually ask a question. One of the TFs told a section of students to assume that a midterm problem was asking about a certain principle; when the midterm was graded they were all marked wrong. Trainwreck of a course.

Simply put, this course had no strengths and it's frankly embarrassing to Yale that it remains in the Blue Book. The course was badly taught, with little to no effort shown by the professor or the TAs. The workload, while minimal compared to other Yale classes, consisted of problem sets and a midterm tangentially related to what we learned in lecture, but the issue was that we never went over anything quantitative in lecture -- the broad ideas taught in lecture really only showed up in ambiguously written short-answer questions on the midterm and final, and had no influence on the day-to-day workload in this class. This was incredibly frustrating to me. If the problem sets are going to be quantitative, teach quantitative stuff in lecture. Leaving it to section leaves us to the mercy of our TAs -- and my TA was not an effective teacher, nor did she even seem to want to show up to section every week. Get better and more enthusiastic TAs, more uniform grading policies, and teach relevant things in lecture. That would be a start.

Also, the problem sets would be very unintuitive (i.e. giving population density per mile instead of sq. mile so instead of taking the area of a circle and multiplying it by density per sq mile you had to do the circumference*density per mile and take the integral over the radius length). Also, the problem set answer keys had frequent mistakes, the Final Review session was very disorganized, and the exam included things we never learned how to do.

This course needs a lot of work...I honestly can't think of any strengths other than the fact that it has the potential to be incredibly interesting, but in it's current form, it should not be allowed to be taught again - it is that poorly organized, and it ultimately hurts the students. There is little to no correlation between lecture and section. Lecture is strictly qualitative, while section is dominated by quantitative stuff. The PSETs are so poorly written that it is hard to understand what the questions are actually asking. It's almost like they are trying to disguise what the question is asking, so you have to read their mind to figure it out. This same trend is also found on the exams, which is extremely frustrating. The exam questions are so poorly written, to the point where it's simply embarrassing how many students got up during the final to ask questions. There were literally lines forming in the lecture hall to have TA's interpret what was being asked. This is incredibly unfortunate when the final exam is worth 50% of a students grade because a extremely large compression curve will ultimately determine every students grade. This basically means you are being graded on how well you can decipher what is being asked rather than how well you know the material. Another problem is the lack of practice problems given. You only have 10 problem sets, and the solution keys posted just have answers and no work/explanations. There is no practice for the qualitative part of the exams either. This course needs some serious revamping to actually help facilitate student learning.

Econ 330 was by far the worst experience I've had in a class at Yale, and I'm a STEM major who took the Bio 101-104 sequence so I know a thing or two about the worst classes Yale has to offer. Simply put, do not take this class. It might seem like a gutty econ class, and it might seem like a cool way to learn about environmental policy from a quantitative standpoint (which is why I took the class). It is neither of those things. The workload might seem minimal, but you won't think this class is a gut when you're up at 2am the night before the problem set is due, wondering which of the contradictory formulas in your TA's section slides vs. your friend's TA's slides will actually get you the points on the problem set. Or when your TA says she'll answer questions on canvas and never does -- or, worse, answers people's questions with incorrect information and then takes points off anyway. The most frustrating thing about this class was that the level of intellectual challenge was relatively low, but wading through the seemingly irrelevant lectures and contradictory section slides to find the few helpful pieces of information to do the problem sets and study for the midterm and final made it feel like the hardest class I had this semester -- simply because there was no effective teaching on the part of the professor or the TAs. An illustrative example: people were literally lining up in the aisles of SSS during the final today to ask the TAs what the two questions in the quantitative part of the final exam meant. They couldn't even write a two-question final without confusing at least 75% of the class. If that doesn't scare you, I don't know what will.
